titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I rose shortly after six this morning, and immediately began upon my customary occupation— Finished reading the Book of Tobit, and began the Wisdom of the Son of Sirach. I observe that the German Translation of the apocryphal Books is from originals altogether different from the English translation— The foundations of the stories are the same, but they seem to be told by two different persons.— The Ecclesiasticus is the best of the apocryphal Books, and worth more than all the rest put together. My next care was to bring up the remaining arrears of my Journal, and close the record of the departed year— After accomplishing this, I walked to the Summer Garden Bridge, and breakfasted immediately after my return— Heard Charles read his fable, and closed the account of the last-year in my Book of family Expences— Prepared also my quarterly account, to be sent to the Secretary of State; and began a letter to my Mother— During the twilight, I took a ride with my wife and Charles, and walked an hour within doors after my return. We dined at five— Mr Krehmer sent me some English Newspapers with which I wasted a long hour after dinner— In the Evening I finished reading the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown— I am not worthy to admire it, as it deserves— His methodical arrangement is not so obvious as that of Cicero, and he does not so well observe the rule of Unity— But Aristotle had not then given his laws, and I am not sure that the architecture of discourse had been taught upon the same principles in the prior schools— Auger says there is a latent concatenation in the various parts of the harangues of Demosthenes— I shall endeavour to find it out— As to the merits of the Cause, on the first and third points of the accusation against Ctesiphon, the defence appears to me complete: but on the second, the place of proclamation; though he produces a law, authorizing it in express terms, Eschines I think has proved that this law did not apply to the case. But the point itself was not proper to be made—it was a captious law-trap of a special pleader.— Who could endure the thought that such a Cause, should have been decided on a question whether the crown should have been proclaimed at the Pnyx, or upon the Theatre? Auger says that Demosthenes was not strong upon this Article— I think the letter of the law was against him— But on the great issue of the Cause, the merits of his administration, he comes out gloriously triumphant. It is impossible now, reading him in a translation and in cold blood, not to be carried away with the exalted sublimity of his sentiments, and to kindle with the fire of his patriotism— On the whole in comparing the two Orations, there appears to me less superiority of talent, than of character in Demosthenes over his rival.— The palm of genius it might perhaps be difficult to assign— But the soul of Demosthenes was higher toned. The personal ribaldry that each of them pours forth against the other is extremely disgusting— Our very newspapers at present are not so bad. Eschines repeats at least twenty times the reproach that Demosthenes had fled, at the battle of Cheronea— Demosthenes takes no direct notice of the charge, and only in one passage, asks if he was to have been able by himself alone to overpower the whole army of Philip? The passage where he undertakes to prove that even if the disastrous issue of his policy could have been foreseen with certainty, it would still have been the duty of Athens to have pursued it, is a model of reasoning as well as of sentiment— Demosthenes was lavish of figures— Eschines ridicules several of his expressions, which are harsh but full of meaning; such as that the Priestess at Delphi Philippized—and that Eschines and others like him had tippled away the liberties of Greece at Philip’s table— The figures of Demosthenes are short, obvious, and taken from objects not of profound Science, but of common observation— It is not necessary to suppose him to have been a man of any considerable learning.— I had just finished the Oration for the Crown when I was called in to Dr Galloway— The German and French newspapers were brought in about eleven at Night, and I sat reading them untill between twelve and one.— Part of the President’s Message at the opening of the Session of Congress was in the Hamburg Correspondent.

2. It was after Sunrise this morning when I rose; and I had long morning visits from Mr Nancarro, lately arrived from America— From Mr Ecky, just returned from Moscow—from Mr Fisher, and from Mr Woodward— The weather being stormy, and a remnant of my cough kept me confined to the house— I wrote nothing but the journal of yesterday, and in the Evening read part of the Oration of Demosthenes upon the Embassy— Auger calls it the prevarications of the Embassy— The latin translations call it the false Embassy— The Greek work is not susceptible of translation.— It would properly be called the Impeachment of Eschines for Bribery and Corruption, in receiving money from Philip, and betraying his trust as an Athenian Minister—the charges are that Eschines had 1. deceived the people by false official reports 2. had prevented them from learning of Demosthenes, the truth 3. had counselled them to measures contrary to their interests 4. had executed none of their orders 5. had been purposely guilty of delays pernicious to the Commonwealth, and 6. for all these acts of treachery had, together with Philocrates, been paid by Philip.— Philocrates he says acknowledged and gloried in having received Philip’s money— Nothing like proof of this offence is produced against Eschines, but the whole issue of the Cause is
rested upon presumptions and conjectures. To understand this harangue as well as all the other political Orations of Demosthenes it is necessary to be minutely acquainted with the History of Greece at that time— I met with an occurrence this day which gave me some concern— A man who keeps a fruit-shop brought me a bill of near 300 Rubles for fruit, due some of it more than a year, and the greatest part seven or eight months—which had been regularly charged to me in Waldstein’s monthly bills, and which I had as regularly paid him from month to month.— It is among the inconveniences of my residence here, and of my ignorance of the language, that I have been compelled to trust to this man— Many of the shop-keepers cannot write and therefore can give no Bills— I cannot read or understand the Bills of those who can— And this fellow has thus, and in several other cases that I have detected misapplied the money that I have paid to him to discharge these Bills, and left them thus to be demanded again of me.

3. I was up again about 7. O’Clock, and read, wrote and walked before Breakfast, according to the regulated distribution of my time. I also wrote two short letters this day— Mr Lange a French Merchant who is going to America, came to request letters of recommendation, and brought me one from the French Ambassador, soliciting them in his behalf.— The fruit-seller came again to dun for the money due him by Waldstein; which I promised that I would make him pay, or have him sent to prison— We have also been obliged to dismiss the woman who furnished us with butter, milk and cream—on discovering, that she had lately got into the habit of furnishing about three pounds, and charging me for five, every week— I mention these Circumstances, because they and many others of a like kind, force themselves upon my attention and time to my great annoyance.— In the Evening, I finished the Oration of Demosthenes upon the Embassy, and began the answer and defence of Eschines— The Attack is much inferior to the Oration for the Crown, which indeed was delivered thirteen years after— The method is imperfect, and not well observed— As to the merits the cause of Demosthenes was weak— The charge of bribery is the only substantial one of the accusation, and it is not proved by any evidence adduced— The personal invective is incessant; the jokes about Eschines as a Stage-player of third rate parts heavy, and repeated to satiety— The private anecdotes, particularly that of the Olynthian woman, insulted by Eschines, at table and in drink, disgusted even the Athenians— On the whole I think differently from Auger, when he says this is not the least pleasing performance of the great Orator; though it is the longest.

4. Mr J. W. Patterson called upon me this morning to ask for a Passport to go to France; upon which he has at length again concluded. Mr Raimbert also paid me a morning visit, and brought with him a present of porcelain for my wife, and for Charles; and another for myself, of which he requested our acceptance— I gave him many thanks for us all, and assured him that being fully sensible of his kindness and attention, I should feel an additional obligation to him if he would take them back—it being a principle which I had found it necessary to adopt from the first day that I became a public man, never to accept for myself or my family, while I held any public Office, a present of more than trifling value, from any person— That this principle was not only the result of my own sense of propriety, but was altogether conformable to the general Sentiment of my Country, which was more punctilious on this subject than any European Nation, and which was peculiarly strict with regard to their Ministers abroad. Mr Raimbert accordingly took the things home with him again— He appeared to feel a little mortification, but he expressed his approbation of my motive. The refusal of presents is one of the occasions on which I have found it most difficult ever since I have been in the public service to act with perfect propriety; and that difficulty becomes not a little aggravated, when they are offered to my family and not to myself— Were it possible for me to prevent it, not the value of a dollar should be offered by any body to any of us; but those who forbear presenting any thing to me sometimes address themselves, where refusal may not be thought my duty, and those who begin with trifles, which it would be affectation, rather than virtue to reject, rise gradually to articles of Cost and value which render it indispensable to recur to the standard of spotless integrity— I have heretofore accepted from Mr Raimbert presents of fruit and other small things, which it would have been ridiculous to reject on the ground of a scruple, and which I could not refuse on any other— But this time the gift would have been of a value which I could not have received without feeling uneasy, for it hereafter— The perfect line between self-denial and self-indulgence may not always be clear, but the principle of temperance has self-denial for its essence; and even excess on that side is better than the slightest deviation upon the other.— I dined at the French Ambassador’s with a Company of about fifty persons,
the common diplomatic company— My next neighbours at table were Count Bussche, and the Grand-Veneur Narishkin— Count Romanzoff told me that he had received a Courier from Paris, and that there were two letters for me, which if I had not already received, would be sent me this Evening.— That he had the papers containing President Madison’s Message, which recommended serious and energetic measures, but complained alike against both France and England— It also mentioned Russia; but in terms peculiarly gratifying to him.— I came home immediately after dinner was over, but was disappointed in the expectation of receiving the letters which the Count had promised me— I finished reading the Oration of Eschines upon the Embassy, and also read over again Plutarch’s life of Demosthenes in Langhorne. Setting prejudice aside I think Eschines upon the Embassy, superior to his rival. It is generally considered unquestionable, as it was believed by the Athenians that Eschines had really been bribed by Philip, and if he was the accusation of Demosthenes was just— But take nothing but the two Orations as the foundation for a Judgment, and you must pronounce in his favour— He strenuously denies the bribery— He appeals to the knowledge of his hearers against many of the material facts, alledged by Demosthenes, and disproves by testimony all the others— His narrative sheds ridicule upon Demosthenes without measure. His argument is more compact and methodical—his tone of discourse milder and more temperate—his appeals to his own services and those of his family, in the style of conscious innocence; his peroration as Auger says a Master-piece of the pathetic. He vouches Phocion, as one of his official defenders— Plutarch doubts whether these discourses were ever delivered, but others say that Eschines was acquitted only by a majority of thirty votes— Mr Fisher and Mr Patterson spent part of the Evening with the Ladies.

5. I rose at 5. and had six hours of employment and exercise before Breakfast— Were perfect regularity in the distribution of my time practicable, this would be my constant course— Mr Hollins came here this morning for his Passport which I gave him; and he was here again in the Evening— As were Mr Harris, and Mr Woodward— I took my second walk before dinner; but my cough still hangs about me, and is occasionally troublesome. Mrs: Adams was taken suddenly this Evening, with great violence with rhumatism in the back of her neck— She suffered extreme pain great part of the Night— I was up untill near two in the morning— From Breakfast time I wrote little during the remainder of the day— I received the two letters mentioned to me by Count Romanzoff— They were from Mr J. S. Smith at Paris— Read two Sermons in the English Preacher— Against idle curiosity; and on the impossibility of serving God and Mammon— I also read a few Sections in Paley’s Horae Paulinae— The argument is ingenious, but I know not whom it is intended to answer— It is to make the history of St: Paul as told in the Acts, and the Epistles of St: Paul, prove, each the authenticity of the other; by coincidences of time, place, and Circumstances, manifestly accidental, and not attributable to design.

6. My anxiety left me short repose— At 5 this morning I was again up— Mrs Adams continued extremely ill the whole day, and I was myself not well— The cough has not yet left me— I walked out however before breakfast, and went to three Churches— The Vosnesensky, or Ascension, The Roman Catholic Jesuits; and the Kazan— I found the ordinary services performing in them all; but nothing more than usual— It is here Christmas day.— Mr Patterson called upon me for his Passport— I received it afterwards from the French Ambassador, and sent it to him by Mr Fisher who also called to see me this morning— I received a second packet from Count Romanzoff, which had been brought by his Courier from Paris; it was a letter from Mr Russell; and a packet which Mr J. S. Smith while in London, intending to enclose to the American Minister at Paris had by mistake superscribed to me— It contained a number of letters for Americans at Paris— I enclosed it again addressed to Mr Smith, and sent it to Mr Patterson. I wrote several letters of introduction for Mr Lange; and read in Auger—Vol. 4. The Oration of Demosthenes against the Law of Leptines— This law, abolished all the exemptions from certain burthensome charges, enjoyed by certain individuals, under grants from the People.— Leptines made an exception only for the descendants from Harmodius and Aristogiton. It is an admirable Harangue, though in a style altogether different from that of the political harangues— He reasons upon the general principle—the wisdom of granting exemptions as rewards for public services—upon the usage—the practice of Athens from the eldest times— From the injustice of taking back immunities from individuals, to whom they were become as absolute property— From the policy, of maintaining the character for generosity and magnanimity, which had
always belonged to the Athenian name— He gives instances of several persons by name, who enjoyed these exemptions, and who could not without the highest injustice be deprived of them— He engages to propose another Law; a better remedy for the abuse which that of Leptines was intended to correct—which was, to authorize public accusation against any person who should obtain public exemptions without having deserved them.— He considers and refutes the arguments in favour of the Law of Leptines— In short this discourse contains every thing that eloquence can perform; excepting method— I was so weary and drowsy when I read it, that many of its merits doubtless escaped me— My power of application was feeble— I closed the Evening before ten O’Clock.

7. Rose by full day-light, between eight and nine O’Clock— I therefore omitted altogether the walk before breakfast— Morning visit from Mr Montreal— I took a ride in the Sleigh with Charles. Paid a Visit to Mr Dana, but did not find him at his lodgings. Afterwards walked— In the Evening I read the Oration of Demosthenes against Midias— Auger says it is one of the best— I think it inferior to that on the Law of Leptines— Midias had struck Demosthenes, at the public Theatre, while Demosthenes was in the exercise of his Office as Choregus— He had also outraged him in many other particulars— Demosthenes urges that these offences were so numerous and aggravated that Midias deserved to be punished with Death, or at least with the Confiscation of all his Estates; which were great; for one of the topics most frequently recurring in the Oration, is the injustice and danger of suffering rich men to be guilty of such acts of violence with impunity. This Oration however was never delivered, for in that against Ctesiphon, Eschines reproaches Demosthenes for having compounded for this insult, with Midias for a sum of Money. This office of Choregus was a burdensome charge, which Demosthenes had voluntarily assumed, upon a principle of public Spirit— He expressly says that he was then only thirty-two years of age. He represents the Choregus as a sacred character, and the offence of striking him as a species of Sacrilege— It is remarkable how the antient Greeks associated in their manners the practices of religion with those of amusement— Their theatrical performances and other sports were all religious solemnities— The Christian religion has assumed a different spirit— It retains nothing but music as an appendage of festivity to religious rites; and music only of the grave and solemn kind— The Choregus among the Athenians whose business was to superintend and direct the musical performances at the Games, was thus a very important personage; and the public amusements were as essential in the estimation of the people, as their most serious affairs.— Dr: Galloway spent upwards of an hour with me in Conversation this Evening. Mrs: Adams continues very ill; and was in severe pain almost the whole of this day.

8. Morning visit from Mr Hazard, who arrived the day before yesterday from Archangel.— The day being fine though cold, I took a long ride with Charles in the sleigh— We cross’d the river, and went round by the house where we resided last Summer; the snow beyond the river appears to be between two and three feet deep, and the roads through the lanes are scarcely passable— After returning home, I took a long walk before dinner— Employed the Evening in writing and reading— Read the Orations of Demosthenes against Conon, and against Androtion— The first is a case of what our law would term assault and battery; the complainant’s name was Aristo, and according to the usage of that time the Oration is in his name, though composed by Demosthenes— It is short, and consists of the same topics which we often hear urged in causes of the same description, in our own Courts— The Orator in this and in all his orations upon individual accusations, cautions the judges to guard themselves against the supplications and tears of the other party— He speaks with horror of Conon’s proposition to swear by the head of his children; but does not say to swear what.— The Cause against Androtion arose peculiarly from the manners and Institutions of Athens— It was a question about a Crown like the famous case of Ctesiphon— Androtion had solicited a Crown, for the Senate of the preceding year— A Law, ordained that a crown should not be demanded for any Senate; unless during their year of service, they had equipped Gallies (no number is mentioned) for the Commonwealth— That Senate had equipped no gallies— The question was whether notwithstanding the Law, the People had a discretionary power to grant a Crown, if they pleased— Demosthenes contended they had not— There is more subtlety than solidity in his reasoning; and he mingles with it incessant invectives against Androtion. It is said to have been laboured by the author with extraordinary care— There are good passages in it, but it is wanting in interest— Demosthenes wrote it, not in his own name, but in that of one Diodorus, of whom nothing is otherwise known.

9. This is the third day successively that I have risen by daylight—and this occasions a corresponding arrangement of my time— After breakfast I rode out with Charles in the sleigh, and went round by the Nevsky Monastery, with the expectation of seeing the frozen flesh market; but found it was entirely gone— In returning, I left the Sleigh opposite the Summer Garden and walked home— Dined with Mr Smith at the Chevalier de Bray’s— The Ladies were invited, but the illness of Mrs Adams prevented them from going— I was acquainted with scarcely any of the Company, except the family. Mr and Madam Livio were there; and Mr and Miss Lesseps. Before returning home I paid a visit to the Chevalier Bezerra, whom I found muffled up in his night-gown with the prevailing Cold and Cough— General Armfeldt was there— A man who has had a period of celebrity, and a very chequered life— Since the conquest of Finland by Russia, having his Estates in that Province he has become a Russian Subject and is distinguished highly by the Emperor— His conversation is interesting, but a very prominent feature in it is Vanity.— He talks much of himself; and told us how he was dining the other day with the Empress-Mother, and a Gentleman whom he did not know, but whom he found to be Mr Paschkoff made him a present of a horse— How he had lately bought a horse for which he had paid 3000 Rubles— How, being at Paris in the year 1801. he made Buonaparte his enemy forever by two things—first by taking it into his head not to go to Court—then the first-Consul’s—though many German Princes then went to Court— And secondly because at the Te Deum for the Peace with England at Nôtredame, he Armfeldt being much annoyed by a woman in the crowd behind him, whom he did not know, and Mr Jackson the English Minister, enquiring who she was, and insisting she must be an acquaintance of Armfeldt, he at last in a moment of indiscretion said—Eh bien, je vous dirai qui c’est— C’est la Déesse de la Raison— Which the first-Consul overheard— Cast a furious look at him, and never has forgiven him since— There was a Lady also paid a visit at Mr Bezerra’s, while we were there— A MadamSister to Count Orloff— I came home about nine in the Evening— Mrs Adams continues still so unwell that my own health is affected by her illness.— She was this day obliged to try the effect of a blister.

10. I had an entirely sleepless Night— My Cold and cough have left me in a state of relaxation, and of nervous agitation, which is exasperated by the illness of my wife, and the sickly condition of my family— With a stomach also weakened; so that although I was yesterday very cautious; the Chevalier de Bray’s dinner probably contributed to my loss of rest during the Night— I rose about seven; and read, wrote and walked as usual before breakfast.— I had a visit afterwards from Mr Montréal who gave me a french foot ruler, with the new divisions of the meter, on the other side.— I took a ride with Catherine, and Charles, in the sleigh, round by the Tauridan Palace— Mr Lange called upon me for the letters of Introduction I had promised him, and I gave them to him— He told me that he expected to go to-morrow.— Catherine passed the Evening with Mrs Bentzon; and I passed it chiefly with Mrs Adams in her chamber— She is better, though still very unwell. I wrote something this day; but read only a few pages of the Oration of Demosthenes against Aristocrates— This man had proposed a decree, that whoever should take the life of Charidemus, might be seized in any of the Cities in alliance with Athens— Demosthenes in the name of Euthycrates opposes the adoption of this decree— He makes three points. 1. That the decree would be contrary to the Laws. 2. That it would be pernicious to the public interests— 3. That Charidemus is unworthy of such a favour— This is the most regular and methodical division that I have yet met with in the Orations of Demosthenes— His argument on the illegality of the decree, is logical, and acute— He shews it to be incompatible with several Laws on the subject of homicide— He reasons excellently from the Spirit of the Laws, and marks with precision the peculiar force of their expressions— Auger says it is one of the finest of the Orator’s Harangues— The specific question is so much at variance with modern manners, that we can scarcely form a conception how it should ever have been made— But the discussion of principles, the legal disquisition, and the reasoning from general justice and policy, are adapted to every age, and every Country.

11. I went early last Evening to bed, but lay without sleep untill between two and three in the morning; when I rose, lighted a candle, walked about my chamber a few minutes, and took a book with me to bed— After reading about half an hour I found myself dosing, put out the light, and soon fell asleep— I slept untill day-light, about 8 O’Clock, and rose, as well as from a good Night’s rest— In the day-time I rode with Charles in the sleigh, to the Nevsky Monastery, after stopping at one of the plate-shop’s; from the foundery I walked home, leaving Charles to return in the sleigh— Received the Notice for the Court, and the Ball in Domino’s on Monday. Mr: Dana spent an hour with me, this Evening— Mrs Adams is better; and came to table with us at dinner; but has still a severe cough— I finished reading the Oration against Aristocrates— The part of the argument intended to prove the unworthiness of Charidemus, enters into so many minute
historical circumstances, and introduces so many names of persons altogether unknown to me, that I have not a distinct idea, either of the facts or of the reasoning— On the whole I think this as Auger calls it, one of the best Orations— It contains a number of good moral and political general observations— There is a long passage in it, repeated from that on the Government of the State— It concludes with a recapitulation of the Laws which the decree of Aristocrates would have violated— It is throughout the most regular of the Orations that I have yet read.

12. I had a very good Night’s rest, and rose at the dawn of day; if at this Season the day can be said to dawn— I read and took my usual long walk before breakfast—also the short one at dusk of Evening, from 4. to 5. afternoon— The Chevalier Bezerra had sent me word that a Gentleman for whom he had procured a Courier’s Passport would go by 2. O’Clock on Tuesday afternoon next, and to be prepared for him I wrote to the Secretary of State— Mr Raimbert, Mr Montréal and Mr Fisher paid me visits in the morning; and Mr Harris and General Watzdorf, by anticipation upon the New-Year— These visits together with the writing of my letter absorbed the day so completely, that I lost it altogether as to its appropriate occupations. I had some Conversation with General Watzdorf, on the subject of the Bible— The other day at the Chevalier de Bray’s, in speaking of Chateaubriand’s Itinéraire, the Chevalier had told me that he had been more interested in his account of Athens, than in that of Jerusalem, and I had expressed a preference on the other side— The Chevalier had then extended his observation to the two Nations, and said he thought the Greeks a more interesting People of antiquity than the Hebrews— I had taken the other side of that question too; and said that without intending to derogate in the least from the merits of the Greeks, I thought that the Hebrews, whether historically or philosophically considered were the most interesting people of antiquity. This had led us into a considerable discussion of the subject, and the Chevalier had mentioned the Conversation to General Watzdorf who said he was on my side of the question, generally; but he believed that the Greeks had excelled in the Arts; especially in Eloquence— We had much conversation upon this, in which I found that the General was more acquainted with the Scriptures than Mr: de Bray; and he has naturally founded on this better acquaintance, a higher opinion of them and of the Nation which produced them— For setting prejudices, and all party Spirit aside, I believe that the respect and veneration of any person for the Bible will increase in proportion to the intimacy of his acquaintance with its contents.

13. The Russian new-year commenced as usual by the appearance of all the Russian Servants in my family, in my chamber to present their felicitations, and receive their presents— I had indeed more of them than ever before; Waldstein my Steward being sick, confined to his chamber— He had heretofore taken most of these persons off my hands. About one O’Clock I went with Mr Smith to the Palace— The Circle was held about two, and certainly did not last more than ten minutes. The Emperor and both Empresses made inquiries of the state of health of Mrs Adams; and talked about the prevailing grippe. After the Circle we went, and wrote our names at the Grand Duke Constantine’s, and paid visits in person to Count Romanzoff and the French Ambassador— I then returned home— Had a visit from Mr Hazard— Wrote to my father— Dined at home, and between 8 and 9 in the Evening, went with Catherine again to the Palace to the Ball in Domino’s— Mrs Adams remains too unwell to be able to go out of the house at-all— We called first at Madame Bezerra’s, Catherine being desirous to go, under the protection of a married lady; but they were already gone— We found at the Palace the crowd more excessive than it had been at either of the former years. After being balloted about in the crowd, and with extreme difficulty making our way first into the Hall of St George, and next into the Hermitage we went in to supper soon after eleven O’Clock.— The Theatre room where the tables were laid was ornamented exactly as it had been last year— The Table of the foreign Ministers was not quite full— The Emperor went round the table, and spoke to each of the guests according to Custom. The supper was over in about one hour, and we returned home immediately from the Hermitage without going back to the dancing Halls. The weather has at length set in for Cold— Mr Six used to say that the heart of the Russian Winter was in the first sixteen days of January Old-Style— When I walked out yesterday at 4 in the afternoon Reaumur’s Thermometer was at about 5 degrees below 0. and before midnight it had sunk to 15. It was from 10 to 15 all this day— But the Halls at the Palace were of a heat almost insupportable— The upper windows of the Hall of St: George were thrown open as usual, but scarcely sufficed to refresh the air within.

14. I had morning visits from Mr Harris, Mr Montreal and Mr Williams who is going to Gothenburg to return to America. I promised to ask a Courier’s Passport for him— I made up my packages for the Chevalier Bezerras Courier; enclosed them all
to Mr Russell in London, and carried the packet to Mr Bezerra’s, myself— He was not at home, and I left it in charge to his Porter— I paid visits at Mr Harris’s—to Genl: Watzdorf, at Mr Fisher’s, and Mr Grammann’s— Also to Mr Ducoster and Mr Ingraham; who is laid up with a rhumatism, and is entirely deprived of the use of both his hands— I walked home— We had Evening visits from Mr Harris junr: and Mr Ecky— Mrs Adams continues still very unwell.— The weather remains very cold— I had almost the whole day the usual succession of visits from the Court-domestics, fouriers, messengers, invalids &c, coming for their new year’s tribute— And this day I had one new set of them from Count Romanzoff’s Office— This is a tax of about 300 Rubles twice a year— The new-years day and Easter— But it is constantly increasing— For those who have once found you out, never fail to come again, and on every such occasion there is some new set of these Solicitors, who have discovered you, and come with their good wishes and their claims.

15. The severity of the cold now delays my rising in the morning, untill after day-light, and I find myself so involved in the minutest particulars of our daily household affairs. Waldstein, the last fortnight has been or pretended to be so sick that he could not leave his chamber to come into mine, whenever I sent for him, and yet has been almost every day going out two or three times, and staid out many nights— Several days ago I gave him warning, and told him it was for the last time, that I should dismiss him if it happened again— In the mean time, tradesmen’s bills have been pouring in upon me for articles which I have paid for months ago, upon his book.— I have detected him in so many of these frauds that he has found no means left to deny them, and sent me last Saturday a written statement admitting that he has 800 Rubles amount of debts, without a copeek to pay them— Every day since then he has been going out and passing the Nights and greatest part of the days abroad, and then coming back and being too ill to leave his bed. I had directed him to give up all the keys he had in his care to Thomas— To take the account of the wine in the cellar, and the number of the bottles he should deliver— But as he had been always too ill to take the account, Thomas had left the key with him— We had this day Mr Harris and his nephew, Mr Fisher, Mr Dana, Mr Ecky, Mr Haven, Mr: Williams and Mr Woodward to dine with us— I directed Thomas what wines to take from the Cellar; and after he came from it, Waldstein was sent to the cellar again— He was out all the Evening as he had been all the morning— After our Company was all gone Thomas came and called me to go down to the cellar— The doors of it had been drawn to open, though double locked, by a bolt within to the folding door, being unbolted— Thomas declared he had left it bolted. I now learnt for the first time that the keys to both the outward house doors, one opening to the arch and one to the Street, were lost some time ago— The Cellar doors are just within the entry, and near both the house doors— The Mooshick said that as he came down the Stairs of the Entry, to shut the outer house doors, he saw some person pass suddenly from the cellar, out at the street door— Thomas went to the House where Waldstein’s wife lives, to find him; but the gates were barr’d, and he could not get in. He came back, and broke open Waldstein’s chamber, but neither the key of the cellar, nor the cellar-book were to be found— The cellar was fastened for the Night by a Padlock, and the street door guarded as well as it could be for the Night— I could not ascertain without the cellar-book whether any and what wine was missing.— It was past one in the morning before I could retire to bed— I had taken a walk before dinner, but the rest of the day was so engross’d that I had time neither to write nor read much— Mrs Adams was so unwell that she could not dine with us.

16. I rose this morning some time before day-light and just before breakfast Waldstein came in affecting great amazement, and enquiring what had happened in the house— I directed him to deliver the key of the cellar to Thomas, and ordered them both to take the account of the wines in the cellar— After breakfast I went down and compared the numbers with the Book kept by Waldstein himself. I found there were missing 573 bottles, all of them excepting 101. the choicest and most costly wines I had— I then discharged Waldstein from my service—and ordered him to deliver up the remaining articles with which he had been entrusted; to furnish me a precise account of the persons to whom he was indebted— He came again in the Evening, and I was obliged to order him to be turned out of the house— In the course of the day a number of bills were brought which I had paid to him. Among the rest one from the Baker, who now serves the family. He told me that the Baker who had served us while we lived in Plincke’s house had also a Bill of nearly 300 Rubles, unpaid— I shewed him the Book of bread kept at that time, with the receipt, signed with his name at the end of every month, untill August last inclusive—at which time he ceased to furnish us— The man was astonished, and said he doubted whether the name was written by Mr Schultz himself— I afterwards shewed the Book to Waldstein and asked him who had signed Schultz’s name to the receipts— He said that he, Waldstein had written it.— I rode out in the sleigh with Charles, and paid visits to Mr Raimbert and Mr Montréal— In the
Evening I finished reading the Oration of Demosthenes against Timocrates— It is an accusation for attempting to obtain a Law, contrary to the Laws— A singularity which I knew not how to account for in reading some of the former Orations, but which in this is fully explained. There is a long passage repeated from the Harangue against Androtion, who was also in some sort a party to this case— The object of the Law proposed by Timocrates was to exempt certain debtors to the Treasury, and to Minerva, from imprisonment, provided they could offer bondsmen for security— Demosthenes in this as in all his other accusations urges for the punishment of Death, against the accused. He generally adds however, or the severest penalty that can be inflicted.— Auger in the summary remarks that Demosthenes seldom restricts himself to any regular method in his discourses; and often departs from that which he himself announces.

17. The greatest part of this day I was occupied with Waldstein, and with tradesmen’s bills, brought me with demand of payment, for which I have been regularly paying him these fifteen months— This and the necessity of providing for the daily wants of the family, detained me untill the hour of dinner at home; so that I did not this day go out at-all.— The Evening was engaged in the same manner, and at last in writing— I received this day the notification from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, for the annual celebration of to-morrow; including the notice that if the cold should prevent the calling out of the troops for the parade there will be no Court.

18. I rose and read again by Candle-light; and took my walk before breakfast— Just as I was going out the messenger from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin came to inform me, that owing to the Cold, 11. degrees (Reaumur) the order for the Court had been countermanded, as well as for the Parade— On returning home from my walk, I found a crowd collected from the Palace to the upper temple, where the consecration of the waters was to be made.— After breakfast I rode out and paid a visit to Count Bussche, whom I found ill in bed; and with whom I had an hour’s conversation— He finds his household affairs as troublesome as I do mine— He had a French Cook; and upon his questioning something in his Accounts the fellow, said that Germans might be treated so, but Frenchmen should not, and he would go and complain to the Ambassador. the Count told me that Violet had been to offer his service to him, but he had taken another— I paid a visit to Mr: & Mrs: Bentzon but they were not at home— In the Evening I read the two Orations of Demosthenes against Aristogiton— Auger doubts of their genuineness— They certainly differ much from the usual manner of Demosthenes, and resemble more the style of Cicero— Yet they are in many respects still so much like Demosthenes, that I incline to think them his— There is more declamation and less Logic than he is accustomed to give; but they are too good for an imitator—or to have been left as derelicts, by any other Orator— It was an accusation of Aristogiton for speaking in public while he was a debtor to the Treasury— The Common Places about the sanctity of the Laws might be introduced, because as to the question at issue the case was too plain to admit of much argument. Lycurgus had spoken before Demosthenes on this same accusation; but the latter says the Judges will not be affected by the Harangues of either; having all decided the Cause before they came from home— Mrs Bentzon paid the ladies an evening visit— Catherine only received her— Mrs A. still unwell.

19. I find my cold and hoarseness returning for the third time— The return of this distemper is very common among those who have been afflicted with it— Charles and the infant, both have their Coughs returning with additional severity— The disorders in our domestic economy occasioned by Waldstein’s villainy still give me much trouble and vexation— I settled this day one Bill, for articles furnished, since his last Accounts, and which had of course not before been paid.— Received a packet from Mr Erving at Copenhagen, with various enclosures; among the rest, slips of newspapers containing all the numbers of the Review of R. Smith’s pamphlet.— I walked before dinner— In the Evening I read the Sermons 9. 10. 11. of Vol. 4. in the English Preacher— On the Union of Wisdom and Innocence; and on the Love of God—these two are by Bishop Butler, whose style is so bad that I can hardly understand him— Read also a few Sections of the Horae Paulinae— But the teizing vexations arising from the discomposure of my household affairs, and much more the illness of my wife and children give me so much uneasiness that I have not tranquility of mind sufficient to read with suitable profit— This Evening a fire broke out at the Palace of Annitschkoff, so lately fitted up by the Emperor for his Sister the Grand-Duchess Catherine; which burnt for several hours. Received notice of a Court mourning for the Duchess of Anhalt-Dessau—one Week.

20. Walked out this morning before breakfast.— On returning home I found Waldstein, and three of the tradesmen with Bills for which I had paid, or which were contracted expressly against my orders— I turned him out of the house, and settled the bills on terms which were equitable, and which satisfied the claimants— I walked again before dinner. Madame Bezerra and Madame Colombi visited the Ladies.— In the Evening I read the three Arguments of Demosthenes against Aphobus his guardian, and the two against Onetor— I have now come in course to the Private Causes— The manner is still evident in them; though they were the Orator’s first performances—

21. Visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Nancarro— I went to the shops and purchased a pound and a two pound nest of weights— Waldstein has stolen those I had before— After returning home I weighed them— They have the stamp of public authority; but the pound weight, weighs 36. grains Troy weight, less than the one I had before.— It took me the whole Evening, and I neither wrote nor read any thing.— In the morning, I finished reading the Apocrypha in the German translation— The two Books of Esdras are not included in it; and the Books are arranged in a different order from those of the English and French Bibles.

22. Morning Visits from Mr Fisher and Mr Linn of Philadelphia, Mr Williams who came to inform me that he intended to go next Saturday, and to whom I gave a Passport, and from Mr Harris, who brought me a slip from the New-York Gazette of 16. Novr: last, containing the correspondence between the Secretary of State, Mr Monroe, and Mr Foster the British Minister relative to the affair of the Chesapeake frigate. I had also two men, who came to me to offer their services, in the room of Waldstein, neither of whom suited me— In the Evening I read the Speeches of Demosthenes against Nausimachus and Xenopithes—against Olympiodorus—and against Leochares.— The first is a cause of two Wards, against the four sons of their Guardian—the second a question between two claimants of an Estate, as next of kin to the deceased—the third is between a claimant as next of kin by blood, and a claimant by virtue of adoptions— These are all discourses resembling those of Isaeus— The next, against Macartatus respects a succession, concerning which there is a Speech of Isaeus— I consulted the notes I had taken when reading the Speeches of Isaeus, in Sir William Jones’s translation.— My Thermometer at 12. below 0—Reaumur. But it is in a Southern exposition, surrounded by the neighbouring buildings— On the quay it is from 3. to 4. degrees colder. I began this morning to read the German New Testament.

23. I had a long visit this morning from the Chevalier Brancia, and much conversation with him upon political subjects. I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Williams, and I completed a letter to my brother. Received the Notice from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies for a Circle at the Winter-Palace, the day after to-morrow, being the Empress’s Birth-day— Mrs Adams rode out, the first time since her illness, and took Charles with her— I walked before dinner— I think I shall rise no more by Candle light this Winter, and I consider my resolution as having in a great measure failed— It has been defeated by sickness— Whether I shall have the Spirit to resume it, depends upon the will of Heaven.

24— Morning visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Harris, and Mr Prevost, the Secretary of the French Embassy; he came to ask for the return of Chateaubriand’s Itinéraire, for the Ambassador who is sick—confined to his house— Mr Williams was here in the Evening; ready to go— I had received from Count Romanzoff his Passport, but asked him to delay his departure untill the day after to-morrow morning; before which I could not be ready for him with my letters— I was indeed myself ready for him this Evening; but the letters are to be copied, which will employ the day to-morrow— Mrs Bentzon spent the Evening with the Ladies, and Mr Woodward also paid them a visit— But I was so much engaged in writing, that I could not leave my Chamber.— I walked an hour before dinner. The weather continues growing gradually colder— The thermometer—Reaumur was last Night atand not under 15 this whole day. Waldstein’s wife came here this day in great distress, real or pretended; saying that he had disappeared from the house where she lives; and she knew not where he was gone— That he had already been three days absent, and that she was afraid I had put him into the Police.

25. At twelve O’Clock I went with Mr Smith to the Winter Palace, expecting an ordinary Circle, on account of the Empress’s birth-day; instead of which we were regaled, with the most unpleasant and dangerous part of the Ceremony which had been postponed from the 6th: and which I had flattered myself we should escape, this year— We were introduced first to the Hermitage, by the door from the Grande Millionne, and soon after were conducted to the great Hall upon the Quay, to witness the filing off of the troops before the Emperor— The two Empresses came, sufficiently muffled up in furs and went out upon the Balcony— Reaumur’s thermometer was from ten to twelve degrees below 0. the precise degree of Cold which was alledged last week for omitting the Parade, and the Court— It was indispensable to follow them out upon the Balcony; bareheaded, without Pelisse—with silk Stockings and thin shoes. They both immediately and strongly recommended to us to go into the Hall, and after a very few minutes I took them
at their word; not however untill I had been thoroughly chilled by the Zephyr from the Quay— The troops were more than an hour filing off; and Count Maistre and the Chevalier Bezerra stood it out almost the whole time— The other members of the Corps Diplomatique all withdrew into the Hall, which was itself abundantly Cold— The French Ambassador, who has been very ill, and several days confined even to his bed, was out on horseback in the suite of the Emperor. He came up however before the troops had all pass’d, and in time to make his Compliments to the Empresses— The true Courtier’s stuck to the Balcony at the risk of their lives; but I thought my privilege as a Republican would be an apology for me, and that I should be doubly ridiculous to stand there, cap in hand, shrugging my shoulders before the two Empresses, and my teeth chattering and my limbs shivering with cold.— About three O’Clock we were released and I came home— Immediately afterwards I went out again, and called upon Mr Schenbom the Swedish Chargé d’Affairs to ask of him a Courier’s Passport for Mr Williams to serve him in Sweden— He promised to send it to me to-morrow by Noon; and perhaps with it a packet for Baron d’Engeström— He said he had been very unwell; and not out of his house for a Month. I went with Mr Smith and dined at Mr Raimbert’s— There was only one Gentleman, an Officer of Engineers there; besides the family— After dinner I called at Mr Krehmer’s— He now is Mr Raimbert’s next door neighbour— But they were not at home— On my own return home I found myself quite unwell; but was up untill past one in the morning, making up packets for Mr Williams.— Madame Colombi and her Sister spent the Evening with our Ladies.

26. Occupied all the morning in writing letters to be sent by Mr Williams— At noon I received Mr Schenbom’s Passport, and packet for him; and about 2 in the afternoon he came and took the remainder of his despatches, and pursued his journey from this house— I took my walk before dinner, and in the Evening read Sermons 12. & 13. Vol: 4. of the English Preacher; on the Christian Ornament of a Good Life— And on the moral infirmity of human Nature— Read also several Sections of the Horae Paulinae— The weather has moderated by the Thermometer, and become more uncomfortable by the wind. I find that I took again a bad Cold yesterday, as was to be expected.

27. Rose and read again by Candle-light, though troubled much with my Cold and hoarseness, and though my bed-chamber and writing-chamber are so cold that I can neither write nor read, nor even sit in them comfortably— I have undertaken to go through the Winter without heating the stove, in my bed-chamber; and the stove in my writing chamber is heated only once a day— I found no inconvenience to this, untill the present spell of severe cold, during which the thermometer in my bed-chamber has gradually descended to two degrees of Reaumur above 0. and a white frost in the night settles upon my windows.— My writing chamber is at 10 at night and at 7 or 8 in the morning— The degree of temperature at which I am sensible neither of heat nor cold is not under 12 nor over 14— I walked this morning about an hour before breakfast— In the course of this day the weather became moderate; and the external air, at only two or three degrees of frost. In the Evening Catherine visited Madame Colombi, and we had a visit from Mr Harris— I read the Oration of Demosthenes against Macartatus, and that of Isaeus for Theopompus the father of Macartatus— I read this last some years ago, in Sir William Jones’s translation of Isaeus— The two speeches are about the same Estate, but not in the same Cause nor between the same parties.— The questions are both intricate and perplexed that in Demosthenes is for the succession of an intestate, between relatives distant from him in the fourth and fifth degrees. One can scarcely imagine a subject less interesting in itself, and there is nothing remarkable in this speech to enliven it.— The style of the two discourses is as much alike, as if it had been by the same hand.

28. Morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Woodward— Received an invitation by Card from Countess Zavadofsky, to attend the funeral of her husband to-morrow morning at 10 O’Clock— I sent a Card in the Evening, but shall omit attendance at the funeral— These notices are by the usage of the Country, sent to all the foreign Ministers, at the decease of the Ministers or Court noblemen of the Country— Attendance is considered as a Compliment, but when there is little personal acquaintance may be omitted— Whenever given it must be in full Court dress;—which is now my chief motive for not attending— Catherine again spent the Evening abroad—with Mrs Bentzon. I read the Speeches of Demosthenes against Beotus—two—both in behalf of Mantitheus—one on account of the name, and the other for the maternal dowry— Beotus was a spurious half-brother of Mantitheus, and had assumed his name— He had obtained legitimation by an artifice of his Mother’s— She had proposed to be put upon Oath concerning her marriage, or rather on the question whether Mantias was the father of Beotus, and had promised to refuse taking the Oath, and to get Beotus adopted by her brother— But when in consequence of this engagement the Oath was tendered to her she took it in due form, and Mantias was compelled to provide for the child— On the
death of Mantias, Beotus and another brother, took jointly with Mantitheus, the legitimate son, equal shares of his Estate— He also usurped the name of Mantitheus; who sued, in one of these cases to prevent his using the name, and in the other to recover one talent as his Mother’s dowry, to be set off from the paternal Estate, before it should be divided between them in equal parts.— The speech against Spudias, is also on a question between two brothers in Law, whether a house which had been mortgaged to the husband of one Sister, should be divided between the two, without deducting first ten mines to discharge the mortgage. The name of the opposite party, for whom Demosthenes wrote does not appear.— against Apaturius— The name of the party here too does not appear— Apaturius sued him as security for Parmeno— He pleads in Bar, as would be said at Common Law—that is he contends that the action of Apaturius against him ought not to be sustained— Against Zenothemis—this is in the name of Demo the uncle of Demosthenes.

29. While I was writing the above, and as I had reached thus far, I received a large packet from Count Romanzoff, enclosing three packets brought from Paris, by a Courier and numbered 1. 2. 3. they had been forwarded by Mr Barlow, through the kindness of the Russian Ambassador Prince Kurakin.— Mr Barlow in his letter to me mentions six packets, but supposes four of them contain nothing but Newspapers and pamphlets, and that they are too bulky to be sent all by one Courier.— The first letter that I opened was from Mr Richard Forrest, a Clerk in the Department of State, and the first information it gave me was of the Death of my wife’s mother, Mrs Johnson, the 29th: of September last, and of Mr Andrew Buchanan, Caroline Johnson’s husband, a few days after. A letter from Mr Hellen, gave a melancholy confirmation to this intelligence— Next came one from my dear and excellent mother repeating the same news, and adding to it that of the decease both of my uncle and Aunt Cranch on the 15th: and 16th: of October—and the further account that my Sister had undergone an operation for a Cancer in the breast.— I had upon receiving these packets so strong a presentiment upon my mind that they would contain tidings of sorrow, that I opened them with a hand more unsteady and faltering than became me— I was prepared to be told of Mrs Cranch’s decease, having known for several months that her recovery was despaired of— That of Mr Cranch was unexpected, though at his great age, (at least 85) it could not surprize me— But Mrs Johnson had enjoyed many years of health, and was scarcely beyond the middle age of life—and of my whole circle of relations and friends in America, there was not one of whose end I could less have expected to hear, than of Mr Buchanan’s—he was in the very meridian of life, and apparently of an athletic Constitution, formed for a long career of health and vigour— In these multiplied instances of mortality among my kindred and friends, God grant that I may learn duly to estimate the frail tenure of human existence, to improve by wisdom and virtue the few remaining days that his Providence may have allotted to myself; and to be also ready for that change through which we must all pass. I pray also to be inspired from above with that firmness which may be needed to meet my own dissolution whenever it may come, or even that of all the dearest friends from whom I am destined, by their departure or my own, still to be separated— In the hands of a merciful God, are the days and destinies of all human kind— May his dispensations be dealt to us in mercy, and the strength to support them be bestowed with gracious indulgence— I was obliged to communicate the knowledge of Mrs Johnson’s death to both her daughters, who were both deeply affected by it— There was a letter for Catherine, from her sister Adelaide; and after the very little preparation that the circumstance admitted I shewed them the letters to me from Mr Hellen and Mr Forrest, and from my Mother— The last was the soothing voice of an Angel.There were besides these several other letters to me public and private— One from Mr Madison, the President of the United States, directing me to stay here in my official character, and thus removing that state of suspense in which I have been living, upwards of twelve Months— Two from Mr Monroe, the Secretary of State; with instructions to the same purpose; and expressing the President’s approbation of my public conduct here.— One from Mr Gallatin, the Secretary of the Treasury, enclosing one from the Treasurer Mr Tucker, with a Bill of exchange drawn by Mr Poletica, upon the brothers Livio— And one from Mr Plumer of New-Hampshire— There were also letters enclosed to my care for Mr Poletica’s brother, for Mr Ivanoff, two, for Princess Gagarin, née de Condoidy, for Baron Rall, two; and for the General of the Jesuits Brzozowski— Also a packet from the Department of State for Mr Hazard— It became necessary to present the Bill of exchange for acceptance— I called for that purpose at Mr Livio’s, and saw him— He accepted the Bill, which being at 30 days sight, he said would be payable the 6th. of February O.S. I left the letters for Mr Ivanoff at Count Romanzoff’s house; those for Baron Rall at his own house, and that for the Abbé Brzozowsky, I went and delivered in person. From Baron Rall’s house I walked home— In the Evening I read the proceedings and Report of the Court of Enquiry, on Commodore Rogers’s conduct, and part of the Documents transmitted to Congress with the President’s Message, at the commencement of the Session— These, with the National Intelligencer of 26. 28 and 30. Novr: and a few sheets of the Journal of the House of Representatives were all the printed part of the packets I received— I had not got through the reading of my letters
when Mr Harris came in, with an eagerness of curiosity, and a struggle to suppress it, which affected his voice and in some degree his breathing. I had nothing to tell him which could gratify his expectations.— He asked me if I had not received a packet from Count Romanzoff with despatches from America— I said I had, and that I had seen by the Messengers Book, there was also one for him— He gave me to understand that he had not received it, having gone out from home, about two hours before— But I had seen his receipt on the Messengers Book, when he had brought my packet— Mr Harris’s agitation is nothing very extraordinary— He has indulged the hope of succeeding me in my Office here, and seems to have felt very confident that I should have been definitively removed, and have had the knowledge of it at this time.— He wishes no ill to me; but he supposed I should have been called away to a destination more agreeable to myself than this, and thus made way for his further elevation here—

30. Mr Harris called upon me again this morning, and thinking it would be unkind to keep him longer in suspense; I read to him the passages from the President and Secretary of State’s letters, directing me to stay here; with which he said he was delighted, and added he hoped I should stay at least all the time that he should remain here— I said my stay would not be very long; probably not more than over another Winter, having too many ties that called me home— He had sent me this morning a letter from Dr: Rush, acknowledging the receipt of the ring, which I had transmitted to him, by Mr: Lynch, from the Emperor— I rode out before dinner, and delivered at the houses to which they were directed the letters for Mr Poletica, and for Princess Gargarin— I called also at Mr Hazard’s lodgings, and left for him the packet received from the Department of State— I walked home— Spent the Evening in reading the printed documents received from America.— Charles gives me concern with a severe cold and cough, which has troubled him these two Months, and which like my own has seemed to disappear altogether, and returned time after time.

31. I have these three days endeavoured in vain to find time during the daylight for writing— My usual reading occupies me untill Breakfast, and afterwards visitors and domestic concerns, into the minutest of which I am obliged to enter, snatch away the hours, till I find my chamber darkening again, which is my summons for the exercise of the day— This morning I had visits from Mr Montreal and from Mr Hazard— Madame Colombi and her Sister paid visits to the Ladies. I spent the whole Evening in writing; from which my weak eye, suffered not a little— I received a packet of English Newspapers down to 31. December, with a letter from Mr Speyer, brought by a Russian Courier from Stockholm

Day— The severity of the Cold; personal indisposition, constantly recurring with some diversity of symptoms, and the painful intelligence received from home, have completed the breaking down of the Resolution with which I began the Winter, to rise at an early hour the whole Season through— The ordinary employment of my time has been as during the previous months; but with frequent occasional interruptions— From the morning, I have been obliged to transfer my reading of Demosthenes, untill the Evening hours, and I have found it also necessary frequently to omit that reading altogether—
